unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: One-Proportion $Z$-Test
question_text: In what situation would it be most appropriate to use a one-proportion $Z$-interval?

choices.text: To estimate the average weight lost on a new drug.
To compare the effectiveness of two different drugs.
To determine if students favor one soda over another.
To determine if the elderly have different political views than the youth.
To estimate the ACT score of kids in a certain high school.

solution:
A one-proportion $z$-test would be used to determine the true proportion who prefer one of the sodas. A two-proportion $z$-test would NOT be used here since the proportions are not independent.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect; measuring weight loss would involve means, not proportions of the population.

Choice 'B' is incorrect; proportions could be used here, but one would use a two-proportion $z$-test to compare the groups on each of the drugs.

Choice 'D' is incorrect; this involves two independent proportions (older vs. younger).

Choice 'E' is incorrect; this involves a mean, not proportion.
